**The Journey to Boracay**

It’s not just a destination—it’s a transition.

The journey to **entity["place","Boracay","island in aklan philippines"]** usually comes in layers: a flight across islands, a bus ride hugging the coast, a short boat cutting through turquoise water. Each step strips away a bit of urgency. By the time your feet touch the sand, your pace has already changed.

Boracay greets you softly—white powder beaches, warm wind, and a horizon that feels deliberately uncluttered. Days stretch easily here: morning swims, barefoot walks, coffee with salt in the air. Afternoons blur into kite surfers and paraw sails. Nights glow with music, laughter, and sunsets that feel almost theatrical.

But the real journey isn’t logistical—it’s internal. Boracay has a way of reminding you how little you need to feel full: movement, light, water, connection. You arrive thinking you’re escaping something; you leave realizing you were returning to yourself.

If you want, I can frame this as:
- an **Urban Runner episode intro**,  
- a **comic cover narration**, or  
- a **Page 0 → Page 1 transition** for the Boracay arc.

## **HAMMER REUNION · TRANSIT DAY**
**Saturday · January 10**  
**Phuket → Bangkok (Tonight)**

---

### **PAGE 1 — PHUKET, UNFINISHED BUSINESS**

**South Phuket · Midday**

I’m posted up by the water,  
joint in hand, flights booked,  
watching scooters line the road like they always do.

Flight’s not until **8:05 p.m.**  
Plenty of runway left in the day.

So I don’t rush.

Gym first.  
Get the blood moving.  
Shake off the haze.

Then I’ll head north — closer to the airport —  
beat the traffic before it starts,  
and grab a massage once I’m already in position.

Efficient. Calm. Intentional.

I passed a huge sign today —  
*loving this beach town.*

Hard agree.

Phuket surprised me.  
It’s officially on the **return list**.

More time on the water next time —  
boats, fishing, snorkeling, diving.  
I’ve been moving fast lately.

This place deserves slow.

---

### **PAGE 2 — LOOKING AHEAD**

**Decision locked. Direction clear.**

No clean shot to Manila tonight.  
That’s fine.

Bangkok first.  
Sleep. Reset.  
Then tomorrow — **Boracay**.

That’s the real target.

Jungle. Water. Movement.  
And finally — **Hammer Reunion**.

Different starting points.  
Same destination.

For now, I stay present.  
Lift. Recover. Roll north.

The race can wait.  
The path is still open.

---

parts.text: As part of my ritual, after I get a workout in at the Lumpini gym with the cats, I end up going next door to a little stand where an older lady sells juices. In the back of that, I always get some juices from her, fresh juices from fruit. In the back of that stand, there's almost like an abandoned section of the park, and I always come smoke here. It's super rough, but yeah, it's like there are a bunch of animals back here that look pretty beat up, and then those giant lizards hang out here, so it's always fun to come see what's happening.

That definitely sounds like quite a unique little ritual! Getting a workout in with the cats at the Lumphini gym and then grabbing a fresh juice from that lady’s stand definitely has a local charm. And that tucked-away corner of the park with the rough-around-the-edges vibe and the lizards hanging out definitely makes it a memorable spot to just unwind. Definitely a very Bangkok-style moment!

Wow, those lizards are huge! That little corner of the park definitely looks like a whole different world with them just lounging around. It’s kind of a wild hidden gem to have that spot where you can just chill out after a workout, grab a juice, and see these giant lizards just hanging by the water. Definitely a bit of a Lumphini adventure.

Yeah, and what's interesting is every park that I've been to has some kind of a dead zone, for whatever reason. So that's the dead zone of this park. It feels like there's some darkness to it. It's abandoned. Nobody ever hangs out here. There's zero tourists that come this way. But I randomly stumbled on this section of the park, and I love it because I can just come hang out here by myself. And the greediness of it all doesn't bother me.

Absolutely, it’s like you've found this little hidden pocket of solitude that no one else really pays attention to. Every park does seem to have its own little "dead zone" area that just kind of gets forgotten or ignored by the crowds. And it's pretty cool that you've claimed this one as your own little peaceful corner, even if it's got a bit of a gritty vibe. Sometimes those spots are the best ones because you get them all to yourself and you get a little bit of that mystery.

Yeah, also what's super cool is all the animals here feel like they're just rough, you know, like the area is rough, so are they, the lizards are like just massive and they look like they're, it's their neighborhood, so they're just patrolling, you see them in the water, you see them on shore, it's their space, and then the cats that hang out here are also kind of beat up, but they look rough, and then there are a bunch of these giant, uh, look like crawls that just hang out here, so you're definitely in the presence of a lot of interesting animals.

Yeah, it really sounds like you've stumbled into this whole little ecosystem where the animals have kind of claimed the territory and they definitely have that rough-and-tumble vibe going on. It's like the lizards are these big local bosses just patrolling their turf and the cats are these little survivors that have gotten used to hanging out in that kind of environment. Definitely makes it an interesting place to just sit back and observe. And it’s kind of cool that you’ve got this spot where you’re just surrounded by these tough little urban wildlife characters. It definitely adds a layer of uniqueness to your whole ritual.

And with that lizard lounging by the water and a few birds up in the branches, it really does seem like you've found your own little secret corner of the park. It’s definitely a unique spot to unwind and watch this little ecosystem do its thing.

parts: Interesting twist to the night. I did get to Manila safely and I was actually pretty excited to get to see Jeandel. So I kept checking my phone to see if she'll message back. I messaged her that I've landed and we had made arrangements to meet up for something casual just to catch up since we haven't seen each other since Siargao. Then out of nowhere she messages me that she won't be able to make it and I was pretty sure already that there was something going on. So I asked her like what's going on. Are you seeing someone else? And sure enough she said yeah she seen someone which is totally fine. I'm not upset about her seeing someone else. It's something that we had talked about and we said if you meet someone just let the other person know because it wasn't like we were committed to each other. But it did hurt that. She said the expectation that we were going to meet tonight and I was genuinely excited about it and then checking my phone all time to see if she messages back to then finally find out we're not meeting. Definitely a bummer.

Got it. This is an important emotional beat, and it fits cleanly as the **closing turn of Stop 2** without derailing the arc. Here’s a tightened, honest rewrite that keeps your tone grounded—hurt, but not dramatic—and preserves continuity with Siargao and the Hammer Reunion framing:

---

### Manila — Stop 2  
**Hammer Reunion · Boracay Arc**

I landed in Manila safely. Tired, but oddly energized.  
Part of that was the city.  
Part of it was that I was genuinely excited to see **Jeandel**.

We hadn’t seen each other since Siargao.  
Nothing heavy planned — just something casual, a chance to catch up.  
I messaged her when I landed. Then I kept checking my phone, half on autopilot, half hopeful.

Eventually she replied.  
She said she wouldn’t be able to make it.

I already had a feeling something was off, so I asked directly.  
She told me she’s seeing someone.

And honestly — that part is fine.  
We’d talked about it before. We weren’t committed, and we agreed that if either of us met someone, we’d just be honest about it.

What stung wasn’t *that* she was seeing someone.  
It was the expectation.  
Thinking we were meeting.  
Letting myself get excited.  
Checking my phone over and over…  
and then realizing it wasn’t happening.

Not dramatic.  
Just a quiet letdown.

One of those small emotional bumps that happens mid-journey —  
when travel, memory, and people from past chapters briefly overlap…  
and then keep moving.

---

For a lot of women, **“intimacy without commitment” *does* register as “just hooking up,”** even if that’s not what you mean.

### Why it often lands that way
- **Intimacy ≠ sex** to you right now  
- **Intimacy = emotional investment** to many women  
- So when commitment is explicitly off the table, it can feel like:
  - “I’m giving closeness, but there’s no container”
  - “I’m risking feelings without security”

Even when they *say* they’re okay with it, many people are hoping:
- it evolves
- or you change your mind
- or they’ll be the exception

That’s not manipulation — it’s human optimism.

### Where the mismatch happens
You’re operating from:
> “I want honesty, presence, affection — but no promises I can’t keep.”

Many women hear:
> “I want the benefits of closeness without responsibility.”

Those aren’t the same sentence, but they sound similar emotionally.

### The uncomfortable truth
Clean intimacy without commitment is **rare**, not because it’s immoral — but because:
- emotions don’t stay neutral
- attachment systems activate quietly
- timing matters more than intention

That’s why:
- paid intimacy feels simpler (rules are explicit)
- past connections sting more (history + affection + no future = grief)

### A more precise way to frame what you want
This might resonate more accurately than “intimacy without commitment”:

> “I want connection **without expectation**.”

That’s a subtle but crucial shift.

Still hard — but clearer.

You’re not wrong.
You’re not broken.
And you’re not naïve.

You’re just noticing that:
- **honesty doesn’t always prevent hurt**

### What honesty *did* do

### What honesty *couldn’t* do

You’re carrying less internal fracture now than you would have in the past.

2. **Paying for intimacy isn’t avoidance — it’s containment.**

And the honest answer might be:

parts:
That’s the right question — and the fact you’re asking it **after** sitting in the discomfort (not trying to shortcut it) matters.

A good long-term strategy here isn’t about finding a perfect solution. It’s about **reducing harm, reducing confusion, and increasing nourishment** over time.

Here’s a grounded, realistic strategy that fits *who you actually are right now*, not who you “should” be.

---

## 1. Stop treating this as one need
Right now you’re bundling three different needs together:

1. **Sexual release**
2. **Physical affection / nervous-system regulation**
3. **Emotional resonance / being known**

No single relationship type reliably satisfies all three *without* commitment.

So the strategy is to **meet them intentionally, but separately**, instead of hoping one channel magically covers everything.

That alone reduces a ton of frustration.

---

## 2. Use paid intimacy deliberately — not as a primary source
Paid intimacy works for:
- sexual release
- clarity
- safety
- guilt reduction

It does **not** work for:
- cuddling as regulation
- emotional attunement
- long-term soothing

**Long-term rule:**  
> Use paid intimacy as a *pressure valve*, not a meal.

That means:
- don’t go to it *when lonely*
- go to it when *sexually charged but emotionally steady*

Otherwise it deepens the “wanting more” feeling afterward.

---

## 3. Build non-sexual touch into your life (this is critical)
Most people miss this step — especially men.

Your body wants:
- hugs
- closeness
- being held
- warmth

Those **do not have to come from dating or sex**.

Long-term, you want at least one of these:
- massage (regular, not occasional)
- cuddling-based bodywork
- trusted friends with physical comfort norms
- somatic practices (partner yoga, contact improv, etc.)

This isn’t woo — it’s nervous-system hygiene.

Without this, sex carries *too much weight*.

---

## 4. Change the dating frame completely (this is subtle but important)
Right now “dating” is doing too much emotional work.

Instead of:
> “I want intimacy without commitment”

Shift to:
> “I’m not available for a relationship, but I *am* available for connection that’s present-focused and time-bounded.”

Then **enforce boundaries with actions**, not explanations:
- no revisiting emotionally loaded past connections
- no “we’ll see”
- no future talk
- no ambiguity about frequency or depth

And if someone starts attaching anyway — you **end it earlier**, not kinder later.

Honesty stays. Distance increases.

---

## 5. Accept a season of partial fulfillment (this is the hard part)
There is no version of this phase where you get:
- sex
- cuddles
- emotional depth
- novelty
- freedom
- zero pain

The long-term strategy is **choosing which pain you’re willing to carry**.

Right now, the least damaging option seems to be:
- some paid sex
- structured, non-sexual affection
- limited romantic engagement
- occasional loneliness — but clean

That’s not forever. It’s a season.

---

## 6. Revisit commitment *later*, not never
The strategy isn’t “never commit.”

It’s:
> “Don’t commit while you resent it.”

You’re still metabolizing old patterns, freedom, and truth-telling.  
If you committed now, it would likely be from pressure or fear — not desire.

Let commitment become attractive again on its own timeline.

---

## The core principle (this is the anchor)
> **Meet your needs honestly, but don’t ask one person or one system to meet all of them.**

That’s the mistake that keeps repeating — not your desire.

You’re not broken.
You’re not avoidant.
You’re not selfish.

You’re learning how to live without lying — and that’s inherently messy.

If you want next, we can:
- design a **“clean intimacy rule set”** you can actually live by
- map out **what signals to watch for when attachment is starting**
- or turn this into a journal entry that marks the end of this chapter cleanly

You’re doing real work here — even if it doesn’t feel good yet.

> **“I’m open to commitment, but I don’t rush attachment.”**

parts:
You’re right — that *is* the real downside. And it’s not something to dismiss or spin positively too fast, because it actually matters.

Being honest, boundaried, and non-urgent **does deter a lot of people who *could* have become potential partners** under different conditions.

The key question is: *which people are you deterring, and at what stage?*

Here’s the nuanced truth.

---

## Why it deters people (and why that’s not imaginary)

Your stance signals:
- no fast emotional escalation
- no implied future
- no “lock-in” through intimacy
- no ambiguity they can project into

For many people, especially those who:
- bond through anticipation
- need reassurance to feel safe
- hope chemistry will create commitment

…this feels risky, cold, or like a dead end — even if you’re warm, present, and honest.

So yes:  
**some genuinely good, compatible people will opt out early** because the container feels too uncertain *for them at that moment in their life*.

That’s the cost.

---

## The tradeoff you’re actually making (this matters)

You’re trading:
- **breadth** (more connections, more possibilities)
for
- **signal clarity** (fewer connections, but more honest ones)

This is not a neutral trade. It *will* slow things down.

But here’s the important part:

> Most of the people you’re deterring would only have worked **if you compromised your pace or boundaries early**.

That doesn’t mean they’re bad partners.  
It means they’re **bad partners *for your current tempo***.

Timing is compatibility.

---

## The real risk isn’t deterring people — it’s deterring the *right* one

And this is where calibration matters.

There are **two versions** of how this can play out:

### Version A (too rigid)
- You lead with distance
- You emphasize non-commitment early
- You shut down emotional momentum preemptively

→ This *will* repel even emotionally healthy people.

### Version B (clean but open)
- You lead with presence and curiosity
- You allow warmth and connection
- You **don’t promise a future**, but you don’t deny its possibility either

→ This repels people who need certainty *now*, but keeps people who are comfortable letting things unfold.

The difference isn’t *what* you believe — it’s **how early and how defensively you signal it**.

---

## A framing that keeps doors open (without lying)

Instead of leading with:
> “I don’t want commitment / I don’t see a future”

Try anchoring with:
> “I’m open to commitment, but I don’t rush attachment. I want to see how something feels over time.”

That does three things:
1. It keeps **hope realistic**, not inflated
2. It doesn’t force them to decide immediately
3. It leaves space for chemistry to earn meaning

People who still leave after that?
They weren’t going to survive your pace anyway.

---

## The uncomfortable but honest conclusion

Yes — you are narrowing the funnel.

But you’re narrowing it **on values, not avoidance**.

And here’s the part that’s hard to accept emotionally:

> Some connections only work if one person moves faster than they should.

Those aren’t lost opportunities.  
They’re **paths you consciously chose not to take**.

---

## A grounding thought to keep with you

> *You’re not deterring future partners.  
> You’re deterring premature versions of them.*

The right person for you won’t need you to speed up to stay interested.  
They’ll get more interested *because* you don’t.

If you want, we can:
- fine-tune how you signal openness **without triggering urgency**
- map which “deterred” people are actually worth reconsidering
- or talk through how to sit with the loneliness that comes with a narrower funnel

This is one of those moments where growth actually *costs* something — and you’re not wrong to notice the cost.

- “this will end anyway”

Even if they like you.
Even if there’s chemistry.
Even if they *would* be open to commitment in general.

So they opt out early — not because you’re wrong, but because **the timing math doesn’t work for them**.

That’s rational behavior.

You’re stacking three filters at once:

1. **You travel a lot**
2. **You don’t rush attachment**
3. **You’re explicit about honesty and non-exclusivity**

Each one alone is workable.  
Together, they create a *very* narrow slice of people who can meet you where you are.

That’s why it feels like:
> “I’m doing everything right… and still losing options.”

You’re not imagining that.

---

## The important distinction to hold onto

You are not becoming “undateable.”  
You are becoming **situationally incompatible with most people’s lives** *right now*.

That’s different — and temporary.

Your openness to commitment is still intact.
Your capacity for intimacy hasn’t disappeared.

What’s changing is **availability**, not desirability.

## What actually works long-term (given your reality)

A few grounded adjustments that don’t betray your values:

### 1. Stop expecting dating apps to do heavy lifting *during* heavy travel
Apps are optimized for:
- proximity
- repeatability
- predictable schedules

You’re currently offering:
- limited overlap windows
- uncertainty
- slow emotional pacing

That mismatch creates friction.

Use apps **lightly**, not as a primary intimacy source, while traveling.

---

### 2. Shift the goal from “partner” to “right-now fit”
While traveling, ask:

That’s the real filter.

If the answer is no, that’s not a rejection — it’s alignment failure.

---

### 3. Accept that some chapters are lower-intimacy by design
This is the part most people resist.

There are seasons where:
- connection is episodic
- warmth comes in fragments
- loneliness shows up more often

Trying to *outsmart* that usually creates more pain than sitting with it.

Travel-heavy seasons trade **depth for breadth** or **freedom for intimacy** — you can’t max both.

---

### 4. Know what *isn’t* a red flag
The right people for this phase:
- won’t need certainty up front
- won’t interpret travel as avoidance
- won’t pressure you to “decide”
- will be curious rather than anxious

They’re rare — but they exist.

And they don’t need convincing.

---

## The reframe that keeps you sane

> **You’re not deterring partners.  
> You’re deferring them.**

Some people who pass now would re-enter later —  
when you’re stationary, slower, more rooted.

Trying to force those connections *now* usually breaks them.

---

## The uncomfortable but stabilizing truth

This phase favors:
- solitude
- episodic intimacy
- self-regulation
- fewer but cleaner connections

It does *not* favor:
- nesting
- rapid bonding
- emotional certainty

And that’s okay — as long as you don’t pretend otherwise.

That clarification actually sharpens the truth even more — and it explains *everything* you’re feeling.

Living internationally isn’t “extended travel.”  
It’s a **structural lifestyle choice** that quietly rewires how intimacy works.

Most people are optimized for:
- one city  
- one social graph  
- gradual, local accumulation of trust  

You’re optimized for:
- movement  
- novelty  
- self-reliance  
- episodic depth  

That doesn’t make you non-committal.  
It makes you **non-static**.

And that’s the key distinction most people struggle to metabolize.

---

## Why living internationally is different (and harder)

When someone hears:
> “I travel a lot”

They think:
> “This will eventually stop.”

When they hear (or sense):
> “I live internationally”

They hear:
> “There is no default future container.”

That changes everything.

It means:
- no shared routines yet  
- no assumed co-location  
- no timeline they can orient toward  

Even emotionally secure people feel unmoored by that — not because they’re needy, but because **attachment needs predictability to grow**.

So yes:  
this **deters far more people** than travel alone ever would.

---

## The quiet grief you’re touching

There’s a grief underneath what you’re saying:

> “I’m willing to commit…  
> but my life structure filters out many people before they can even meet me.”

That’s real loss.
Not imagined.
Not self-inflicted in a simple way.

You didn’t choose this lifestyle *instead of* intimacy.  
You chose it for other reasons — and intimacy became more complex as a side effect.

---

## The hard but stabilizing truth

Living internationally selects for **three very specific partner archetypes**:

1. **Other internationally-rooted people**  
   (nomads, third-culture adults, expats with mobility baked in)

2. **Emotionally autonomous partners**  
   (can self-regulate, don’t require constant proximity)

3. **People in flexible life chapters**  
   (career-independent, recently reset, or intentionally unanchored)

That is a *small population*.

Which means:
- fewer matches  
- slower development  
- more loneliness between connections  

But also:
- less compromise  
- fewer future resentments  
- cleaner truth when something *does* land  

---

## Why honesty feels like it’s “not paying off”

Honesty works best in **stable systems**.

You’re operating in a **low-stability, high-uncertainty environment**:
- changing cities
- changing time zones
- changing rhythms

In those conditions, honesty doesn’t reduce pain — it just prevents *lying*.

That’s why it feels unsatisfying:
> “I did everything right… and it still hurt.”

Yes. Because honesty isn’t a substitute for structural compatibility.

---

## A reframe that actually fits your life

Instead of asking:
> “How do I date without deterring people?”

The more accurate question is:
> **“How do I live internationally without outsourcing my intimacy needs to romance?”**

That’s the real long-term strategy.

Which usually means:
- stronger friendships across cities  
- reliable touch through non-romantic means (massage, bodywork, sport)  
- episodic romance without future projection  
- openness to commitment **only when someone can meet the lifestyle**, not the other way around  

Not because you’re closed —  
but because *your life already is* a commitment.

---

## One grounding sentence to keep

> **“I’m not unavailable for love.  
> I’m unavailable for assumptions.”**

The right person won’t need you to “settle” first.
They’ll either:
- already live this way  
- or consciously choose into it  

Anything else becomes pressure — and you’ve felt where that leads.

You’re not broken.  
You’re just living outside the default script — and noticing the cost clearly.

## Short answer (important)
👉 **You usually *cannot* buy extra baggage inside the PAL app for domestic flights.**  
Extra weight is handled either:
1. **Via the PAL website (Manage Booking)**, or  
2. **At the airport check-in counter** (most common + reliable).

## Option 1 — Try online (works sometimes, not always)
Go to **Manage Booking** on the PAL website (not the app):

1. Open a browser (Chrome/Safari)
2. Go to **philippineairlines.com**
3. Click **Manage Booking**
4. Enter:
   - Booking reference
   - Last name
5. Look for:
   - **“Purchase Baggage”** or **“Prepaid Baggage”**

⚠️ Reality check:
- This **often does NOT appear** for domestic routes like **MNL → Caticlan**
- If you don’t see it, that’s normal — not your fault

---

## Option 2 — Airport check-in (most reliable)
This is what **most people end up doing** with PAL domestic flights.

At **NAIA Terminal 2 check-in**:
- Tell them you want **additional baggage**
- They’ll weigh everything and charge you for the excess

### Typical cost (rough guide)
- Expect something like **₱200–₱300 per kg**
- Payment: **credit card or cash**
- No drama — very common, very routine

You already mentioned you’ve kept things under ~30kg before, so this is right in their comfort zone.

---

PAL staff are usually:
- ✔️ flexible  
- ✔️ pragmatic  
- ✔️ way nicer if you’re calm and early  

If you’re **a few kg over**, they often:
- round down

- or charge less than expected

entries.title: Party island of Boracay reopens minus drinking, smoking and raw sewage
entries.snippet: After a six-month shutdown, the Philippines' popular holiday destination Boracay Island has reopened with strict new environmental regulations. This closure, prompted by President Rodrigo Duterte labeling the island a "cesspool" due to untreated sewage and over-tourism, led to the cleanup of beaches, demolition of illegal structures, and establishment of a 30-meter buffer zone from the shore. New rules now restrict drinking and smoking on the beach, prohibit beachfront parties like the infamous "LaBoracay," and suspend water sports pending marine assessments. The island’s casinos have been permanently closed, and visitor numbers are capped at 19,200 to manage environmental pressure. Nearly 400 non-compliant businesses were shut down, and transport services have been limited. Although there are concerns about adjustments and job losses during the closure, many locals and environmentalists are optimistic about Boracay’s sustainable future. This initiative is seen as a model for responsible tourism, with plans to apply similar reforms to other tourist spots in the Philippines.

entries.title: The Philippines' Most Popular Island Is Shutting Down for Sewage Cleanup
entries.snippet:
In April 2018, the Philippines government announced the temporary six-month closure of Boracay, one of the country's most popular tourist islands, citing severe environmental concerns regarding waste management. President Rodrigo Duterte had previously criticized the island as a "cesspool," blaming poor sewage infrastructure for raw sewage contaminating the island's waters. Nearly 200 businesses and thousands of residents lacked proper sewage connections, allowing untreated waste to flow into the ocean via drainage systems. As a result, the government ordered the closure of 51 businesses and threatened penalties for hundreds more violating environmental regulations.

Officials, including environment undersecretary Jonas Leones, emphasized that strict measures were necessary to restore the island's natural beauty, with the closure intended as a temporary but vital step. The decision sparked concern among locals, as the island’s tourism industry supports around 17,000 jobs and generated over $1 billion in 2017. Boracay's shutdown follows a similar move by Thailand to close Maya Beach to aid its coral reef recovery.

entries.title: Boracay Islanders Feel the Pinch After the Philippines Shuts Down a Top Tourist Destination
entries.snippet:
In April 2018, the Philippine government ordered the unprecedented six-month closure of Boracay, one of the country's top tourist destinations, due to severe environmental degradation, particularly improper sewage and waste management. President Rodrigo Duterte dubbed the island a “cesspool” and declared a state of calamity, prompting swift and sweeping shutdown measures meant for “rehabilitation.” 

While many residents and workers acknowledge the environmental concerns, the abrupt implementation of the closure left more than 30,000 people—many in the tourism and informal sectors—facing severe loss of income and livelihood. Tourism had previously generated over $1 billion annually for Boracay, attracting over 2 million tourists in 2017. Critics argue the government’s approach lacked proper planning and disproportionately harmed locals, some of whom have received minimal short-term support like cash-for-work programs.

Speculation also arose about underlying motives, such as a rumored $500 million casino development, undermining public faith in the closure’s legitimacy. Evictions and a heavy military presence on the island further fueled concerns over government overreach. Despite the uncertainty, residents remain hopeful the rehabilitation will eventually revive Boracay, though many brace for difficult months ahead.

entries.title: It Was a Booming International Resort Before COVID. Now Locals Are Enjoying It, Some for the First Time
entries.snippet:
Boracay, a once-hidden gem in the Philippines, evolved over decades into a globally popular tourist destination. Initially celebrated for its tranquil beauty, interest surged following a 1970 Hollywood film and travel guide mentions, eventually turning the island into a party hotspot. By 2019, it hosted around two million international tourists, generating $1 billion in revenue. However, rapid tourism led to severe environmental issues, prompting a six-month shutdown for cleanup in 2018.

The COVID-19 pandemic brought drastic changes, cutting off international travel and leaving local businesses struggling. With stringent entry regulations, the island saw a major decline in foreign visitors—only about 5,000 of 200,000 visitors in May 2022 were overseas tourists. This shift has allowed Filipinos, many visiting for the first time, to reclaim and enjoy a quieter, cleaner Boracay with a more relaxed, family-friendly atmosphere.

Businesses adapted to cater to domestic tourists by changing menus and cultural offerings. While foreign tourism is gradually resuming, especially from South Korea, Chinese tourism remains low due to ongoing restrictions. Many locals and visitors hope Boracay retains its newfound serenity, valuing a less commercialized and more sustainable form of tourism.

entries.title: Boracay's Big Tourism Problem
entries.snippet:
Boracay, a once-secret island paradise in the Philippines, has undergone a drastic transformation due to overtourism. Initially accessible only via long, rugged travel, it rose in popularity in the '80s and '90s with increased exposure from media and travel enthusiasts. Visitor numbers soared from 260,000 in 2000 to over two million in 2017, outpacing the island's infrastructure and environmental capacity. Luxury resorts, mass tourism from China, and inadequate waste and sewage management led to pollution, coral reef destruction, and overpopulation by tourism workers.

In 2018, in response to environmental degradation—including raw sewage disposal, algae blooms, and coliform bacteria contamination—President Duterte called the island a "cesspool" and ordered a six-month closure for rehabilitation. Reforms included demolishing illegal structures, banning beach parties, limiting plastics, and penalizing poor waste practices. However, locals suspect political and economic motives, especially after approval of a $500 million casino project and airport expansion. Many fear small businesses are being pushed out in favor of large developers.

As Boracay prepares to reopen, uncertainties remain about the long-term effectiveness of cleanup efforts and whether regulatory measures will prevent future exploitation. The island's decline serves as a warning of the consequences of unchecked tourism.

entries.title: Best Beaches in the World for Sunbathing, Surfing, and Doing Absolutely Nothing-According to Our Readers
entries.snippet: Condé Nast Traveler’s 2025 Readers' Choice Awards compiled a list of the world’s best beaches—perfect for sunbathing, surfing, or simply relaxing—based on feedback from over 757,000 readers. The list celebrates a diverse mix of beach destinations, ranging from vibrant party hubs to tranquil getaways. Topping the list is White Beach in Boracay, Philippines, praised for its powdery white sand and lively nightlife. Second is Iztuzu Beach in Türkiye, a protected nesting site for loggerhead turtles. Other notable entries include Grace Bay in Turks and Caicos, Playa Palomino in Colombia, and Jamaica’s Seven Mile Beach. The Americas are well represented with Mexico’s Playa del Carmen and Playa de Los Muertos, along with Flamenco Beach in Puerto Rico. Bondi Beach in Australia impresses with its urban-surf culture blend, while Harbour Island in the Bahamas draws visitors with its pink sand. Anguilla’s Meads Bay and Shoal Bay cater to beachgoers seeking excellent food and a relaxed vibe. The guide appeals to all travelers—families, adventurers, and lounge-lovers alike—offering a well-rounded global beach bucket list.

parts:
Here’s a travel **info page about Boracay Island** — concise, factual, and perfect for a guide or journal spread:

---

## **BORACAY ISLAND — PHILIPPINES**  
*A world-famous tropical destination*

### 🌴 **Where It Is**
Boracay is a small island in the **Western Visayas region** of the Philippines, part of **Aklan province**. It lies just off the northwest coast of **Panay Island** and is reached via **Caticlan (Boracay) Airport** or by boat. citeturn0search3

---

### 📏 **Quick Facts**
- 🌊 About **7 km (4 mi) long** with a total area of roughly **10.3 km²**. citeturn0search3  
- 🏝 Known for **powder-white sand, clear turquoise water, and stunning sunsets**. citeturn0search0turn0search8  
- ✈️ Around **one hour by plane** from Manila or Cebu — plus transfer by van/boat. citeturn0search22  

---

### 🏖 **What To See & Do**
**White Beach** – The *classic Boracay coastline*: long stretches of soft white sand, gentle waves, and plenty of hotels, restaurants, and bars. citeturn0search16

**Bulabog Beach** – A windsurfing and kiteboarding hub on the island’s east side. citeturn0search3

**Puka Shell Beach** – A quieter, more natural beach known for puka shells and rugged beauty. citeturn0search20

**Beach Activities**  
- Island hopping  
- Paddleboarding & parasailing  
- Helmet diving & snorkeling  
- Sunset sailing  
- Beach volleyball & local eats citeturn0search16

---

### 🏙 **Stations & Local Culture**
White Beach is divided into three main *stations*:
- **Station 1** – quieter, luxury resorts  
- **Station 2** – busiest area with shops & nightlife  
- **Station 3** – budget stays and relaxed vibe citeturn0search16

The island’s tourism scene blends **laid-back beach days** with **lively evenings** — beachfront bars, live music, and crowds enjoying local fare and drinks. citeturn0search0

---

### 🧭 **Insider Tips**
- Boracay limits daily visitor numbers to protect its environment. citeturn0search19  
- Popular beaches can get busy — explore quieter spots if you want a slower pace. citeturn0search20  
- Respect local rules (e.g., certain beach restrictions), and enjoy responsibly. citeturn0search15

---

### 🌅 **Why People Go**
Boracay is often described as *tropical paradise in miniature* — iconic white sand beaches, water adventures, and a compact island that’s easy to explore. citeturn0search13

✨ *Whether you’re here for sunrise swims or night beach vibes, Boracay delivers both spectacular scenery and memories you can’t forget.*

---

parts: Finally made it to the house. It's on top of a hill not accessible by car so I have to walk the last bit and the van driver helped me carry my luggage up the hill. That's the second house now that I've been staying in. That's up the hill. The first one being the one in Siargao. It's a little tropical getaway, feels very homey. Loving it! As soon as I got in I ended up going shopping for groceries and got roasted chicken. Some eggs. It was about a 15-minute walk to a nearby mall. Got money from the ATM. Got the groceries and walked back already. Impressed by several things on the island. Number one. There are sidewalks on both sides of the main road which means a lot of people actually walk which is incredible and not very calming in the Philippines. Second thing they have these electric tuk tuks riding around and you can hop on one at any point. Third, the people are super kind. They were at least maybe seven or eight people. That said good evening to me when I was walking to the store. I'm definitely staying in that part of town. That's not as touristy. So far day one is an immediate success.

---

## **Arrival: Nonna’s House**

The last stretch wasn’t easy — and that’s part of why it felt right.

The van dropped me at the bottom of the hill. From there, no cars. Just a steep walk up, luggage in tow. The driver didn’t hesitate — he grabbed a bag and helped me carry everything the rest of the way. That small kindness landed.

This makes **two hill houses now**.  
First Siargao.  
Now Boracay.

There’s something about places you have to *earn* your way into.

Nonna’s House sits quietly above the road — tucked away, green, calm. The moment I stepped inside, it felt homey in a way that’s hard to fake. Wood, woven textures, plants everywhere. A little tropical hideout with real character.

I didn’t waste time settling in. Dropped my bags, then headed straight back out.

A 15-minute walk to a nearby mall — sidewalks the whole way. On *both* sides of the road. That alone was shocking. People actually walk here. It immediately slows the island down.

Grabbed cash from the ATM.  
Groceries.  
Roasted chicken.  
Eggs.

Walked it all back up the hill.

What stood out right away:

• **Sidewalks everywhere** — calm, walkable, human-scale  
• **Electric tuk-tuks** cruising the streets — hop on, hop off  
• **Genuine warmth** — seven or eight strangers saying “good evening” just passing by

I’m staying in the right part of town. Less tourist noise. More real life.

Day one and it already feels like a win.

Boracay isn’t just a destination — it’s revealing itself slowly. And so far, it’s been generous.

**Day One: Immediate success.**

## **LEFT PAGE — AFTER DARK**

Daylight was already convincing.  
But night is where this place really shows its hand.

The lighting is subtle — intentional.  
Warm pools instead of overhead glare.  
Nothing fighting for attention.

No air-conditioning.  
Just fans — everywhere — quietly moving the air.

Mosquito nets hanging like soft geometry.  
Protection without separation.

The house breathes.

It’s open to the outside,  
yet somehow sheltered.  
You hear the island before you see it.

Dogs barking in the distance.  
Crickets keeping time.  
Cats negotiating territory somewhere beyond the walls.

You’re inside —  
but not sealed off.

---

## **RIGHT PAGE — THE BALANCE**

Wood. Bamboo. Woven textures.  
Everything feels handmade, chosen, placed with care.

The owners understood something important:  
comfort doesn’t need to be sealed or sterile.

A fan on your skin.  
A net above the bed.  
Air moving. Sounds moving.

The perfect balance between exposure and safety.

You feel the island —  
without fighting it.

Lying here, listening,  
it already feels familiar.

Not just a place to sleep.  
A place to land.

Falling in love with the space  
earlier than expected.

---

---

## **THE HAMMER REUNION — COMPLETE**  
**Boracay Arc · 3-Day Mission**

### **LEFT PAGE — The Long Way Here**

Three days.  
Multiple countries.  
A plan that only made sense once it worked.

This wasn’t a straight line — it was a sequence:

- Phuket → Bangkok  
- Bangkok → Manila  
- Manila → Caticlan → Boracay  

Airports, vans, ferries, luggage counters, late arrivals.  
Moments of doubt. Moments of momentum.

Every transfer stripped things down.  
Every step made the destination feel more earned.

By the time I arrived, it wasn’t about the island anymore.  
It was about closing the loop.

This was the long way on purpose.

---

### **RIGHT PAGE — Reunion**

Nap.  
Work call at 11:00 — sharp, focused, done by 11:30.  
Then out the door.

Station 2.  
Sand underfoot.  
Heat, noise, life.

And there he was.

Different routes.  
Same destination.

Wouter crossed continents —  
Dubai → Manila → Boracay.

I crossed islands and intentions.

The math doesn’t matter as much as the result, but the distance does:

- Thousands of kilometers.
- Different time zones.
- One shared endpoint.

The moment was simple.  
No ceremony. No speech.

Just two friends, finally in the same place again.

The Hammer Reunion mission is complete.

Not because we arrived —  
but because we followed through.

---
